channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: The two Koreas: Could a North-South summit be in the works?
item.description: Kim’s renewed military confidence and Lee’s pragmatic diplomacy create the ideal conditions for a meeting.

item.title: Vietnam’s race between speed and stamina
item.description: To Lam has fast consolidated power, but this new logic of control is not reform in the Western sense.

item.title: The anatomy of hate: How misogyny drives extremist engagement
item.description: Young men are being exposed to online hatred early and often. Intervention is key to countering the breeding grounds.

item.title: Silent Streets and Shifting Norms: Japan’s Weakening Pacifist Movement
item.description: Takaichi’s forward-leaning stance on Taiwan reflects the Japanese public’s decreased opposition to such rhetoric.

item.title: Trump’s Crony Diplomacy
item.description: Under President Donald Trump, entrusting inexperienced loyalists to handle issues of national and global concern has become the norm, and personal enrichment the through line of US foreign policy. The result is the Ukraine "peace deal" Trump's cronies cooked up.

item.title: America’s work-from-home capitals are in a sorry state
item.description: Remote-work cities show signs of strain

item.title: How the G20 Can Lead the Fight Against Global Inequality
item.description: The world is facing an inequality crisis fueled by stagnant wages, eroding social protections, and the extreme concentration of wealth. Reversing these trends requires reassessing the policies that produced them and equipping governments with the information they need to pursue effective reforms.

item.title: Can the Pacific still shape COP31 after Australia’s compromise?
item.description: Even without a co-hosting arrangement, Canberra can still push outcomes that matter for the region.

item.title: How Israel’s Embassy Lost China
item.description: A case study of the tenure of Israel’s outgoing ambassador shows a lack of effort to engage with Chinese thought leaders or combat rising antisemitism – until it was too late.

item.title: The Scars of Partition
item.description: From Ireland to Palestine, the 20th century’s partitions promised stability but delivered bloodshed, animosity, and ethnic cleansing. A new book traces how the breakup of the British Indian Empire unleashed a chain of upheavals that redefined South Asia and shaped the modern world.

item.title: How Trump Could Fix the G20
item.description: With the group's rotating presidency passing to the United States, many expect that Donald Trump’s presence at the helm will further reduce the effectiveness of a once-promising multilateral economic institution. But that need not be the case if Trump focuses on two issues.

item.title: AI is upending the porn industry
item.description: Synthetic smut will soon be flooding the internet, bringing new opportunities and perils

item.title: Many Israelis believe another war with Iran is coming
item.description: The only question is whether it will be sooner or later

item.title: Why Iran is making surprising overtures to America
item.description: Its clerical regime appears to adapting to survive

item.title: Iran’s reformists extend a hand
item.description: The West should heed Iran’s call to restart nuclear talks

item.title: When is a Malaysian footballer not a Malaysian footballer?
item.description: The country is accused of handing out passports to foreign players

item.title: America’s oldest ally in Asia is drawing closer to China
item.description: Thailand increasingly depends on its bigger neighbour for trade and security

item.title: Dr Chatbot is popping up all over China
item.description: What the country learns as a result could change treatments everywhere

item.title: A terrible inferno kills dozens in Hong Kong
item.description: Hundreds are still missing

item.title: “I love the smell of deportations in the morning”
item.description: Through countless emails asking for political donations, Donald Trump is writing the MAGA narrative of his presidency

item.title: Chicago is facing a giant budget crisis
item.description: Will the city choose to spend less or soak business?

item.title: The federal government will now pay for Native American healing
item.description: No, this is not a bizarre MAHA experiment

item.title: MAGA is divided over the promise and perils of AI
item.description: A user’s guide to the battle between techno-optimists and neo-Luddites

item.title: Business
The weekly cartoon
Politics
If the fighting ends in Ukraine, the infighting in Europe will begin
item.description: Beware Europe’s great de-galvanisation

item.title: Macron, Merz and Starmer are forming a new trilateral leadership
item.description: Three leaders struggling at home, but vigorous abroad

item.title: Denmark gets ready to cancel Christmas cards
item.description: The Danish post is the first to end letter collection, but others will follow

item.title: Turkey’s refs are caught up in a huge sports gambling scandal
item.description: The country’s football may be as corrupt as its politics

item.title: Denmark has become a red-tape-free wedding destination
item.description: In much of Europe, getting married is a nightmare for foreigners

item.title: From Nvidia to Nike, American firms face a margin squeeze
item.description: For profits to keep growing, they must elbow their way out of it

item.title: American consumers are miserable. But they keep spending
item.description: Consumer spending and retail sales have decoupled

item.title: Europe is struggling to compete in the second space race
item.description: Its governments are starting to take action

item.title: Observed in the wild: office snackers and foragers
item.description: From the snack cupboard to the coffee machine

item.title: How Pepsi trounced Coca Cola in the Middle East
item.description: Its dominance is entwined with the region’s turbulent politics

item.title: The changing shape of Chinese aid to Africa
item.description: As Western countries cut support, China is unlikely to fill the gap

item.title: Mired in financial crisis, the Houthis resume threats to Saudi Arabia
item.description: But with Donald Trump in the White House, their brinkmanship could backfire

item.title: Armed men take power in Guinea-Bissau, again
item.description: But not everyone is convinced the latest putsch is a real one

item.title: Canada’s indigenous-style prisons are designed to right historical wrongs
item.description: When rehabilitation is the focus, reoffending rates drop

item.title: Uganda’s Fixed Election Belies an Uncertain Future
item.description: President Museveni will be reelected in January. But the country is wondering what comes next.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Identity Quandary
item.description: Even though Hong Kong’s financial sector has rebounded, with a high-flying Hang Seng Index and a return to the top spot in the global IPO rankings, the city is still a diminished version of itself. China’s stifling influence on Hong Kong’s governance has eroded its position as an international entrepôt.

item.title: What China will dominate next
item.description: The country’s high-speed innovation holds lessons for the world

item.title: Self-driving cars will transform urban economies
item.description: A robotaxi boom is coming. The impacts might be broader than you expect

item.title: China’s property market is (somehow) worsening
item.description: Government remedies are not up to the job

item.title: Japan’s big-spending Takaichinomics is ten years out of date
item.description: In a time of higher inflation, a falling yen and rising bond yields make a noxious blend

item.title: Serf Music and Its Alternatives
item.description: In music as in other artistic pursuits, the only true freedom lies in controlling the fruit of one’s creation. AI could amplify this freedom if we act now on behalf of human creators; but as matters stand, it seems well on its way to doing the opposite.

item.title: Narendra Modi plans to free up India’s giant labour force
item.description: Socialist employment restrictions will be swept away

item.title: Nepal’s youth toppled the government. Now they want to remake it
item.description: An infusion of fresh faces, ideas and energy could help pull the country out of its economic stupor

item.title: A shooting in Washington prefigures tougher immigration policies
item.description: National Guardsmen, who were was deployed to protect people, became a target

item.title: Meet the road-building, Muslim-baiting monk who could rule India
item.description: Some see the leader of India’s biggest state as a visionary. Others fear him

item.title: One weird trick to solve the affordability crisis
item.description: If voters dislike big numbers, there is a purely nominal fix

item.title: Europe Must Stop Squandering the Power of Its Purse
item.description: In a time when demands on constrained public budgets are growing, strategic procurement is one of the few measures that can strengthen businesses, reduce emissions, protect public health, and promote economic growth at the same time. But the European Union urgently needs reforms to unlock these benefits.

item.title: Will 2026 Bring Financial Crisis?
item.description: From US President Donald Trump’s weaponization of trade to the erosion of US Treasuries’ status as safe-haven assets and breakneck investment in AI, the last year has shaken the foundations of the postwar global economy. As 2025 comes to an end, we asked PS commentators whether a crisis is imminent, and how economies can mitigate the fallout.

item.title: Ukraine may be a step closer to peace, or to destruction
item.description: A baffling week of Trumpian diplomacy and plotting

item.title: The Paradox of Europe’s Trumpian Right
item.description: How America’s weaponization of ideology could backfire.

item.title: Balochistan Enacts New Law to Criminalize Child Marriage
item.description: The legislation sets 18 as the legal age for marriage for both males and females, but effective implementation will require significant reforms.

item.title: Singapore Orders Tech Firms to Prevent Spoofing of Government Agencies
item.description: The Singapore Police Force says that it has detected an increase in the impersonation of agency names and the "gov.sg" SMS sender ID on major messaging platforms.
